passage:
(1) Birds have remarkable abilities to navigate during their seasonal migrations, often traveling thousands of miles with astonishing precision. Some species return to the exact same nesting sites year after year, demonstrating an incredible sense of direction. Scientists have discovered that birds use multiple navigation methods, enabling them to adapt to different conditions they encounter during their long journeys.

(2) One primary navigation tool birds use is the position of the sun. Many birds can track the sun's movement across the sky and adjust for time of day, essentially using the sun as a compass. What makes this ability even more impressive is that birds possess an internal clock that allows them to compensate for the sun's changing position throughout the day. Some species can even use polarized light patterns visible at sunrise and sunset when the sun itself isn't directly visible.

(3) Perhaps more remarkably, research has shown that many birds can detect Earth's magnetic field, an ability known as magnetoreception. This built-in magnetic compass helps birds determine direction, especially during cloudy days or night migrations when celestial cues are unavailable. Scientists believe birds may have specialized cells containing magnetic particles in their beaks or eyes that function like microscopic compasses, allowing them to sense magnetic north and south.

(4) Stars also play a crucial role in bird navigation, particularly for species that migrate at night. Studies have demonstrated that nocturnal migrants can identify specific star patterns and use the North Star as a fixed reference point. Young birds appear to learn these celestial patterns during their first months of life, creating a mental star map they can refer to during migration. Some birds can even recognize star patterns that rotate around the pole star, giving them consistent directional information.

(5) Birds also rely heavily on geographic features like coastlines, mountain ranges, and rivers as navigational landmarks. Many species follow these natural highways during migration, using them as visual guides to stay on course. Familiar smells and sounds may also help birds recognize specific locations, particularly as they approach their final destinations. This combination of sensory tools and navigation methods demonstrates the remarkable adaptability that allows birds to complete their impressive migratory journeys year after year.

questions.question: According to paragraph 1, birds use multiple navigation methods in order to:

options.B: Adapt to different conditions during journeys

options.D: A method to estimate flight time

options.C: Birds are flying near the equator
options.D: Birds are flying in large groups

According to the passage, which celestial body serves as a fixed reference point for nocturnal migrants?

options.B: They learn navigation skills from older birds
options.C: They create mental maps of star patterns early in life

questions.question: The phrase 'natural highways' in paragraph 5 refers to:

options.D: Paths formed by other migrating animals

options.A: To compare different bird species' migration patterns

options.D: To analyze the environmental threats to bird migration

questions.question: Based on the passage, what is emphasized about birds' navigation abilities?

options.B: Their dependence on other migrating animals
options.D: Their vulnerability to changing weather conditions
